thread.title: Airberlin-Etihad codeshare still questioned | Airports & Routes
thread.title_full: Airberlin-Etihad codeshare still questioned | Airports & Routes content from ATWOnline

author: Kurt Hofmann
title: Airberlin-Etihad codeshare still questioned | Airports & Routes
text:
German aviation authorities are again questioning the continuation of codeshare routes for the upcoming winter schedule beginning Oct. 25 between Etihad Airways and its strategic equity partner airberlin.
The affected routes are between Germany and Abu Dhabi. These codeshare flights generate an additional €140 million ($159 million) turnover per year for airberlin, several German media outlets reported.
Etihad is airberlin’s biggest single shareholder and owns 29.21% of its oneworld partner.
Members of airberlin´s works-council addressed a note to German chancellor Angela Merkel that without this codeshare agreement the situation could be existence-threatening for the financially troubled airline .
Airberlin in Berlin was not able to comment.
Luftfahrt-Bundesamt (LBA), the German aviation authority, checks codeshare deals every time airlines submit winter and summer schedules for flights to and from Germany.
The authority said that codeshare flights for Etihad-airberlin in the last winter-schedule (2014/15) and for the summer-schedule 2015 had been given temporary approval.
Airberlin last year hoped to find a solution for permanent codeshare approval without the continued questioning.
In August, airberlin reported a second-quarter net loss of €37.5 million, widened from a net loss of €8.6 million in the year-ago quarter. First-half net losses were €247.6 million, widened from a €201.2 million net loss in the year-ago period. Airberlin reported a €377 million loss ($458 million) in 2014, deepened 19% from a €315.5 million loss in the year-ago period.
Airberlin CEO Stefan Pichler told ATW in a recent interview that the partnership with Etihad remained on a positive trend. Passenger numbers on shared routes grew during 2014 to over 600,000, an increase of nearly 7%.
